item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 23
item.description: Thursday marked the 118th anniversary of the birth of Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose, an Indian freedom fighter.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man dressed as Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose, a freedom fighter, during an event marking the 118th anniversary of the birth of Mr. Bose in Agartala, Tripura.

item.title: Woman Is Gang-Raped on Order of Village Council in India
item.description: Thirteen people, including the village chief who ordered and participated in the rape, have been arrested in West Bengal, according to Indian police.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Another Rights Advocate, Hou Xin, Is Tried in Beijing
item.description: Hou Xin, a former journalist who participated in a protest against official corruption, is one of at least eight activists in China being tried this week.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Investigative Stories Delve Into the Use of Offshore Companies by Chinese
item.description: The first big stories of the year have come from the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, which had received a trove of financial documents on activity mostly in the British Virgin Islands.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Sun Tiangang has filed a lawsuit accusing the state-owned oil enterprise Sinopec of working with police officials to illegally imprison him for five years.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Embracing the Power of the Internet
item.description: The Internet has had such an impact on our social fabric that the question has to be asked: What should we be doing with it?
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: In Syria Talks, Even the Smallest Details Are Negotiated
item.description: A mediator was laying the ground for face-to-face talks, reflecting the daunting challenges of seeking a political resolution to the conflict.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Lakhdar Brahimi, the international mediator in the Syrian peace talks, with United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Wednesday in Montreux.

item.title: Anti-Immigration Party Occupies the Center of an Uneasy Debate in Norway
item.description: A nation that has long prided itself on its liberal sensibilities is divided by a discussion about immigration and its effects on national identity and the country’s social welfare system.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Cease-Fire in Kiev as Opposition Leaders Meet With Ukraine President
item.description: Opposition leaders said they were prepared to embrace the violent uprising if President Viktor F. Yanukovich does not agree to early presidential elections or make another major concession.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Protesters took cover as water was sprayed from a fire engine on Thursday at the site of clashes with riot police in Kiev.

item.title: News Analysis: Exporting U.S. Rules for Foreign Banks
item.description: Overseas banks like Barclays, Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse have not had to comply with parts of the Dodd-Frank Act.
item.category: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By PETER EAVIS
item.media:description: Deutsche Bank’s offices in Lower Manhattan. The Federal Reserve is expected to end a loophole for foreign banks.

item.title: Mediators Say Truce in South Sudan Is Near
item.description: Both sides have said that a cease-fire would be a temporary measure that falls short of a formal peace agreement and that talks would have to go on.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Russian Court Frees Khodorkovsky Associate
item.description: The order to free Platon A. Lebedev, a business associate of the recently pardoned oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, was in step with a series of amnesties and pardons before the Winter Olympics.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, left, with Platon Lebedev in court in 2009.

item.title: India Ink: Raid in Delhi Neighborhood Rattles African Residents
item.description: Finding themselves under increased scrutiny, many residents of Khirki Extension were fearful about talking about the way they have been treated during their stay in India.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Abe’s Version of History Doesn’t Sit Well With Chinese
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, in his appearance Wednesday at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, said he saw comparisons between Britain and a rising Germany in 1914 and the current tensions between Japan and China.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan arrives at a panel session on Wednesday at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

item.title: Rouhani Says Iran Has No Plan for Nuclear Weapons
item.description: Speaking at the World Economic Forum, Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, endorsed a path of “prudent moderation” in remarks that seemed designed to remold his country’s image.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani on Monday referred to recent cooperation with the United States and other powers as a “major development.”

item.title: Man Released in Australian Open Betting-Related Case
item.description: The arrest of a British man represents a rare attempt to prosecute a person for relaying information from a live sports event.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN MARTIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Tries to Close Provincial-Sized Hole in Economic Statistics
item.description: A combination of accounting methods and local boosterism may be behind the sum of provincial economic figures repeatedly outperforming the national G.D.P.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Workers demolish older buildings in Shanghai in preparation for new construction. Chinese economic reports continue to show discrepancies between national and provincial data.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Web Outage Blamed on Censorship Glitch
item.description: Chinese authorities suggested the massive disruption was the work of hackers. But others cited a malfunction of the government’s Great Firewall, the sprawling, hidden infrastructure used to restrict what ordinary Chinese can see online.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Letter from China: A Race Against Time for a Second Child
item.description: Zhejiang Province has become the first to implement legal changes permitting many couples to have two children, after decades of only one. But elsewhere the wait is agonizing for many couples whose biological clock is ticking.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Although a relaxation in the one-child policy has been announced, laws have yet to be changed in many localities.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Rights Advocate Releases Statement on Goals
item.description: Xu Zhiyong, who is on trial in Beijing and accused of disturbing order by organizing public gatherings calling for equal rights to education and for officials to reveal their wealth, laid out his ideas for the New Citizens Movement.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Police officers in Beijing try to prevent journalists from interviewing Zhang Qingfang, inside the white vehicle. Mr. Zhang is a lawyer for Xu Zhiyong, the founder of the New Citizens Movement who went on trial on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Pankaj Ghemawat, IESE Business School Professor
item.description: India Ink spoke with Mr. Ghemawat, who co-authored a study that measured the globalization levels of 139 countries, about why India ranked near the bottom of his rankings.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Pankaj Ghemawat, professor of global strategy at the IESE business school in Madrid, Spain.

item.title: Watchdog Report Says N.S.A. Program Is Illegal and Should End
item.description: The 238-page report is likely to inject a significant new voice into the debate over surveillance, underscoring that the issue was not settled by a speech President Obama gave last week.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:credit: Christopher Gregory for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, a federal panel, at a workshop about surveillance held in a Washington hotel last summer.

item.title: Texas Executes Mexican Man for Murder
item.description: The state put Edgar Arias Tamayo to death on Wednesday, despite the stated concerns of Mexican officials, Latino advocates and Secretary of State John Kerry that the execution could harm international relations.
item.dc:creator: By MANNY FERNANDEZ
item.media:description: Protesters on Sunday. The sign, with a photo of Edgar Tamayo, says in Spanish, “The town of Miacatlán offers you its support.”

item.title: State Dept. Learned in November of Photos Said to Show Torture in Syria
item.description: The photos seem unlikely to change the American policy of seeking a settlement to remove President Bashar al-Assad but avoiding direct military action.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Ahmad Assi al-Jarba, a Syrian opposition coalition leader, at talks in Switzerland, holding a photo said to be of torture victims.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Ecuador: President to Ask U.S. Officers to Leave
item.description: President Rafael Correa said Wednesday that Washington had too many military officers assigned to its embassy in Ecuador.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Manufacturing Slowdown Carries Over to 2014 in China
item.description: The manufacturing sector contracted in January for the first time in six months as new orders declined, according to a preliminary survey.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
